title: Mountain Warehouse launches T-mall store in China after record first half
text:
0.00 0.00 
The outdoor clothing retailer has opened a storefront on Alibaba's online marketplace ahead of Singles Day, the biggest shopping day of the year 
Mountain Warehouse has turned its eyes to the Chinese market following a record first half by launching a store on T-mall, the online shopping platform owned by retail giant Alibaba . 
The outdoor clothing retailer grew sales by 24.7pc in the first half of the year to a record £59.3m as the unseasonably cool and wet summer drove consumers towards its protective gear. 
Pre-tax profits jumped by 31pc to £4.3m, boosted by increased popularity of its cycling and running ranges . 
Mark Neale, founder and chief executive of Mountain Warehouse, said he was "very excited" to be collaborating with Alibaba, with the launch of the store timed to benefit from Singles Day on November 11 , the biggest shopping day of the year in China. 
Last year, Chinese consumers spent almost £6bn online in just 24 hours. 
"We have been sourcing products from China for over 10 years but this is a huge opportunity for us and demonstrates our flexible approach to international expansion through both traditional stores and digital channels.” 
The London-based company, which will end the year with 225 stores after opening 34 new branches this year, saw internet sales increase by 41.3pc in the six-month period. 
Mountain Warehouse, which opened its first store in Swindon in 1997, now generates almost a fifth of its revenue online. 
Mountain Warehouse created more than 200 jobs in the first half of the year from opening new stores in Eastbourne, Evesham, Cromer, Shrewsbury and Inverness. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) sells more than 12m items a year. 
"We have had another amazing six months, helped by the wet August but with our summer products also selling well earlier in the season," Mr Neale said. 
"I’m delighted to say, as we head into autumn, that this has continued, which means that 2015 is shaping up to be another record year."
